title: HTML
subtitle: Start from zero and build real pages with clear words and many tiny examples.
overview: HTML is the language of web pages. It gives structure and meaning: titles, text, images, forms, and more. We start from zero, explain every new word, and use small, clear steps. Anyone age 6+ can follow and build pages with confidence.
content: You will learn how to write clean, semantic HTML. We will cover the page skeleton, headings and text, links, images and media, semantic layout (header, nav, main, footer), forms, tables, accessibility basics, SEO metadata, responsive images, and best practices.
prerequisites: Nice to have: curiosity and a text editor
outcomes: Create valid HTML pages with a correct head and body
Use semantic elements to structure content and help screen readers
Build accessible forms with labels, input types, and built-in validation
Add images, video, and audio with proper alt text and captions
Use metadata for SEO and social sharing, and ship fast, friendly pages

lessons.summary: Learn what HTML is, the page skeleton, and how to open a page in the browser.

content.value: HTML means HyperText Markup Language. It tells the browser what each part of the page is: a heading, a paragraph, an image, a link, and more.

Use <!doctype html> to tell the browser to use modern HTML mode.

An element usually has an opening tag and a closing tag. The content goes between them. Example:

Tags are case-insensitive in HTML, but write them in lowercase for consistency.
Attributes add extra info to elements. They live inside the opening tag, like href on a link or src on an image.

lessons.title: Headings, Text, Lists, and Links
lessons.summary: Use headings for structure, paragraphs for text, lists for items, and links for navigation.

content.value: Headings create a clear outline. Use one <h1> per page for the main title, then <h2>, <h3>, and so on for sections and subsections.

My Blog

First Post

Hello world!
Do not pick headings by size. Pick by meaning: levels form a logical structure.
Inline text tags add meaning: <strong> for strong importance, <em> for emphasis, <code> for code, <mark> to highlight.

Warning: save your work.

Press Ctrl + S.
Use <strong> and <em> for meaning, not just for styles.
Lists group items. Use <ul> for bullets and <ol> for numbered steps. Each item goes in an <li> element.

Shopping List

  • Milk
  • Bread
  • Eggs
Nest lists for subitems. Keep nesting shallow for readability.
Links connect pages. Use absolute URLs for other sites and relative URLs for pages inside your site.

If you open a new tab, add rel="noopener" to improve security and performance.

lessons.title: Images, Audio, and Video
lessons.summary: Add images with alt text, use figure/figcaption, and embed audio/video with captions.

content.value: Use for images. Always include alt. The alt text should say what the image means or shows.
If the image is decorative only, use empty alt (alt="").
Use <figure> to group an image and its caption. Put the caption in <figcaption>.
Captions help explain context. Keep them short and clear.
Audio and video can have multiple sources. Add controls so users can play/pause. Use <track> for captions (subtitles).

<video controls width="480">
  <source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
  <track kind="subtitles" src="subs.vtt" srclang="en" label="English">
  Sorry, your browser doesn't support embedded videos.
</video>
Always offer captions or transcripts for accessibility.

examples.code: <video controls><source src="clip.mp4" type="video/mp4"><track kind="captions" src="clip.vtt" srclang="en"></video>

lessons.title: Forms: Basics and Labels
lessons.summary: Build simple forms with proper labels, names, and input types.

content.value: A form groups inputs to send data. The action is the URL, and the method is usually GET or POST.

<form action="/subscribe" method="post">
  <label for="email">Email</label>
  <input id="email" name="email" type="email" required>
  <button type="submit">Subscribe</button>
</form>
Always connect <label> with its input using for and id for better accessibility.
Use the right input type to get built-in validation and better keyboards on phones.

<input type="email" required>
<input type="password" required>
<input type="number" min="0" max="10">
Add name attributes. Without name, the input’s value won’t be submitted.
Group related controls with <fieldset> and <legend>. Use <textarea> for multi-line text and <select> for options.

<fieldset>
  <legend>Contact</legend>
  <label>Name <input name="name" required></label>
  <label>Message <textarea name="message"></textarea></label>
</fieldset>
Place help text near the input. Keep labels short and clear.

examples.code:
<label><input type="checkbox" name="tos" required> I agree</label>
<label><input type="radio" name="size" value="s"> Small</label>

lessons.title: Forms: Validation and Submit
lessons.summary: Use HTML validation attributes and understand GET vs POST basics.

content.value: Validation helps users fix mistakes before sending data. HTML has built-in checks like required, minlength, maxlength, min, max, and pattern.

<input name="username" required minlength="3" maxlength="16">
<input name="age" type="number" min="0" max="120">
<input name="zip" pattern="\d{5}" placeholder="12345">
Use title on inputs with pattern to explain the expected format.
The form method decides how data is sent. GET puts data in the URL (good for search). POST sends data in the request body (good for forms).

<form action="/search" method="get">
  <label>Query <input name="q"></label>
  <button type="submit">Search</button>
</form>
For sensitive data, use POST. Do not put secrets in URLs.
You can tell the browser not to validate with novalidate, or per input with formnovalidate on a submit button.

<form novalidate>
  <input name="email" type="email">
  <button type="submit">Submit without checks</button>
</form>
Prefer keeping validation on. It helps users and reduces errors.

lessons.title: Tables for Data
lessons.summary: Create accessible tables with headers, captions, and scopes.

content.value: Tables are for tabular data, not for layout. Use <table> with <thead>, <tbody>, and <tfoot> when needed.

Monthly Sales
MonthTotal
Jan$100
Feb$120
Use <caption> to describe the table. It helps everyone, including screen reader users.
scope on <th> tells which cells the header relates to (col or row). This improves screen reader navigation.

<th scope="col">Price</th>
<th scope="row">Total</th>
Avoid complex merges unless needed. If you use colspan/rowspan, test with screen readers.

lessons.title: SEO and Page Metadata
lessons.summary: Use proper titles, descriptions, social meta tags, and language to help search and sharing.

content.value: The <title> is the page title in the browser and search results. Make it short and clear.

<head>
  <title>Best Pasta Recipes</title>
</head>
Keep titles under ~60 characters when possible.
Add a meta description to summarize the page. It may appear in search results.
<meta name="description" content="Easy pasta recipes with simple ingredients.">
Use one <h1> in the body for the main topic. Keep content relevant to the title.
Use Open Graph and Twitter Card tags for social sharing previews (title, description, image).

<meta property="og:title" content="Best Pasta Recipes">
<meta property="og:description" content="Simple and tasty.">
<meta property="og:image" content="https://example.com/pasta.jpg">
<meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image">
Set <html lang="en"> to help screen readers and search engines.

lessons.title: Accessibility Basics (a11y)
lessons.summary: Make pages usable for everyone: labels, alt text, landmarks, focus, and ARIA basics.

content.value: Accessibility means everyone can use your site. Start with semantic HTML: it gives roles and behavior for free.

Contact Us

We are here to help.
Prefer native elements over custom ones. They handle focus and keyboard by default.
Every input needs a programmatic label. Use <label for> or wrap the input, and ensure a matching id.

<label for="email">Email</label>
<input id="email" name="email" type="email" required>
Place error messages near the input and connect them using aria-describedby if needed.
Use alt text. Provide visible focus styles with CSS. Keep tab order logical. Avoid tabindex > 0 unless you know why.

Skip to content

Add a skip link as the first focusable element so keyboard users can jump to main content.

lessons.title: Responsive Images and Performance
lessons.summary: Use width/height, loading=lazy, srcset/sizes, and <picture> for the best image experience.

content.value: Give images width and height attributes to reserve space and reduce layout shift.
Even if CSS scales the image, width/height attributes help the browser plan space.
Use loading="lazy" for below-the-fold images to speed up the first paint.
Do not lazy-load images that are immediately visible when the page opens.
Use srcset and sizes so the browser can pick the best image for the device.
Keep file sizes small. Prefer modern formats like WebP/AVIF if supported.

options: As small as possible while looking good

lessons.title: Embedding Content and Loading Scripts
lessons.summary: Use iframe safely, and load scripts with defer/module for performance.

content.value: <iframe> embeds another page. Use sandbox and allow attributes to control what it can do.

<iframe src="https://example.com" title="Example"
        width="600" height="400" loading="lazy"
        sandbox="allow-scripts allow-same-origin"
        referrerpolicy="no-referrer">
</iframe>
Set a title on iframes. Keep permissions minimal.
Load scripts with defer so they don’t block HTML parsing. Use type="module" for modern JS and automatic strict mode.

<script src="app.js" defer></script>
<script type="module" src="main.js"></script>
Place critical scripts near the end of <head> with defer, or before </body> if needed.
Use rel preconnect or preload for critical resources. Keep third-party embeds as few as possible.

<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com" crossorigin>
<link rel="preload" as="image" href="hero-1200.jpg">
Measure performance. Avoid blocking scripts that slow down first paint.

examples.code: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/xyz" title="Intro Video" loading="lazy" allowfullscreen></iframe>

options: Load without blocking and run after parsing
